Variable linear motion means velocity changes over time, shown by a non-zero slope on a v-t graph.
From t = 0 s to t = 1 s, velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s; line is horizontal.
No change in velocity from t = 0 s to t = 1 s means no variable linear motion in this segment.
From t = 1 s to t = 3 s, velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = -2 m/s; line is diagonal.
Linear decrease in velocity from t = 1 s to t = 3 s indicates constant negative acceleration and variable linear motion.
From t = 0 s to t = 1 s, constant velocity means no variable linear motion; from t = 1 s to t = 3 s, velocity changes, indicating variable linear motion.
Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, starting after t = 1 s.
